prompt: The researchers returned back to the laboratory to replicate the initial findings.

choices.B: to the laboratory
choices.C: to replicate
choices.D: NO ERROR

explanation: "Returned" already means to go back, so "back" is redundant. The concise phrasing is "returned to the laboratory."
source_section: Section II: The Editor's Lens and Economy

prompt: Each and every participant in the clinical trial must submit written consent prior to enrollment.

choices.B: in the clinical trial
choices.C: written consent
choices.D: NO ERROR

explanation: "Each and every" is a redundant expression. Either "each" or "every" alone conveys the same meaning more concisely.
source_section: Section II: The Editor's Lens and Economy

prompt: The advance planning committee scheduled the symposium for early March to accommodate visiting scholars.

choices.B: scheduled the symposium
choices.C: to accommodate
choices.D: NO ERROR

explanation: "Planning" inherently involves looking ahead, so "advance" is redundant. "Planning committee" is sufficient.
source_section: Section II: The Editor's Lens and Economy

prompt: The study's end result confirmed that biodiversity loss accelerates in regions with high deforestation rates.

choices.B: confirmed that
choices.C: accelerates in regions
choices.D: NO ERROR

explanation: A "result" is already something reached at the end, making "end" redundant. "Result" alone is concise and clear.
source_section: Section II: The Editor's Lens and Economy

prompt: The two laboratory teams merged together to form a single interdisciplinary research group.

choices.B: merged together
choices.C: a single interdisciplinary
choices.D: NO ERROR

explanation: "Merged" already means to combine into one, so "together" is redundant. The concise phrasing is simply "merged."
source_section: Section II: The Editor's Lens and Economy

prompt: The professor gave a brief summary of the lecture's key points in a short, concise manner.

choices.B: lecture's key points
choices.C: short, concise manner
choices.D: NO ERROR

explanation: "Short" and "concise" mean essentially the same thing, creating a pleonasm. Either word alone would suffice.
source_section: Section II: The Editor's Lens and Economy

prompt: The autobiography of her life details her transition from practicing clinician to full-time researcher.

choices.B: details her transition
choices.C: from practicing clinician
choices.D: NO ERROR

explanation: An autobiography is by definition the story of one's own life. "Of her life" is a pleonasm. "Her autobiography" is sufficient.
source_section: Section II: The Editor's Lens and Economy

prompt: There are several scholars who believe that the methodology is fundamentally flawed.

choices.A: There are several scholars who believe
choices.B: that the methodology
choices.C: is fundamentally flawed
choices.D: NO ERROR

explanation: "There are several scholars who believe" is a wordy construction. A more concise version would be "Several scholars believe." The expletive "there are" and the relative clause add unnecessary length.
source_section: Section II: The Editor's Lens and Economy

prompt: The department chair, despite the fact that funding was available, declined to authorize the new hire.

choices.B: funding was available
choices.C: declined to authorize
choices.D: NO ERROR

explanation: "Despite the fact that" is a circumlocution. The concise alternative is "although" or "even though," which conveys the same meaning in fewer words.
source_section: Section II: The Editor's Lens and Economy

prompt: It is essential that researchers are able to access the archived datasets in a timely fashion.

choices.B: are able to access
choices.C: the archived datasets
choices.D: NO ERROR

explanation: "Are able to access" is wordy. The concise equivalent is "can access," which conveys the same meaning in fewer words.
source_section: Section II: The Editor's Lens and Economy

prompt: Due to the fact that the sample was contaminated, the researchers discarded the entire batch.

choices.B: Because the sample was contaminated, the researchers discarded the entire batch.
choices.C: Owing to the fact that the sample was contaminated, the researchers discarded the entire batch.
choices.D: On account of the fact that the sample was contaminated, the researchers discarded the entire batch.

explanation: "Due to the fact that" is a circumlocution for "because." Choice B is the most concise and direct option while preserving the original meaning.
source_section: Section II: The Editor's Lens and Economy

prompt: The sociologist conducted an investigation into the various factors that play a role in urban poverty.

choices.B: The sociologist investigated the factors that contribute to urban poverty.
choices.C: The sociologist conducted an investigation into the various different factors that play a significant role in urban poverty.
choices.D: It was the sociologist who conducted an investigation into those various factors playing a role in urban poverty.

explanation: "Conducted an investigation into" is a wordy way of saying "investigated," and "play a role in" can be replaced by "contribute to." Choice B is concise without losing meaning.
source_section: Section II: The Editor's Lens and Economy

prompt: The researchers collaborated together on a joint project examining antibiotic resistance.

choices.B: The researchers collaborated on a project examining antibiotic resistance.
choices.C: The researchers collaborated together in a joint and shared project examining antibiotic resistance.
choices.D: Working collaboratively together, the researchers examined antibiotic resistance in a joint project.

explanation: "Collaborated together" is redundant because collaboration already implies working together. Additionally, "joint" is redundant with "collaborated." Choice B removes both redundancies.
source_section: Section II: The Editor's Lens and Economy

prompt: In the event that the grant application is denied, the principal investigator will seek alternative funding sources.

choices.B: If the grant application is denied, the principal investigator will seek alternative funding sources.
choices.C: In the event that the grant application happens to be denied, the principal investigator will then seek out alternative funding sources.
choices.D: Should it come to pass that the grant application is denied, the principal investigator will seek alternative funding sources.

explanation: "In the event that" is a circumlocution for "if." Choice B is direct, concise, and preserves the full meaning of the original sentence.
source_section: Section II: The Editor's Lens and Economy

prompt: The data that was collected by the team was analyzed in a manner that was both rigorous and thorough.

choices.B: The data collected by the team was analyzed rigorously and thoroughly.
choices.C: The team analyzed the data rigorously.
choices.D: The data that had been collected by the team was then analyzed in a rigorous and thorough manner by them.

explanation: Choice C eliminates the passive construction, removes the unnecessary relative clause "that was collected," and recognizes that "rigorously" already implies thoroughness. It is the most concise option that preserves the essential meaning.
source_section: Section II: The Editor's Lens and Economy

prompt: The new innovation in gene therapy has the potential to completely transform the entire field of oncology.

choices.B: The innovation in gene therapy has the potential to transform oncology.
choices.C: The new innovation in gene therapy has great potential to completely and totally transform the entire field of oncology.
choices.D: The new and novel innovation in the field of gene therapy could potentially transform the entire field of oncology completely.

explanation: "New innovation" is pleonastic because innovations are by definition new. "Completely transform the entire field of" is wordy when "transform oncology" conveys the same idea. Choice B removes all unnecessary words.
source_section: Section II: The Editor's Lens and Economy

prompt: At this point in time, the university is in the process of reviewing its admissions criteria.

choices.B: At this juncture, the university is currently in the process of undertaking a review of its admissions criteria.
choices.C: The university is currently reviewing its admissions criteria.
choices.D: At the present moment, the university is engaged in the process of reviewing its admissions criteria.

explanation: "At this point in time" is a wordy substitute for "currently" or "now," and "is in the process of reviewing" is wordier than "is reviewing." Choice C conveys the same meaning in the fewest words.
source_section: Section II: The Editor's Lens and Economy

prompt: The students were asked to revert back to the original version of the thesis draft.

choices.B: The students were asked to revert to the original version of the thesis draft.
choices.C: The students were asked to go back and revert to the original prior version of the thesis draft.
choices.D: The students were asked to revert back once again to the original version of the thesis draft that came first.

explanation: "Revert" already means to return to a previous state, so "back" is redundant. Choice B removes the redundancy while preserving the sentence's meaning.
source_section: Section II: The Editor's Lens and Economy

prompt: The provost made the decision to postpone the vote for the reason that several committee members were absent.

choices.B: The provost decided to postpone the vote because several committee members were absent.
choices.C: The provost made the decision to postpone the vote due to the fact that several committee members were absent.
choices.D: Making the decision, the provost postponed the vote for the reason that several of the committee members were not in attendance.

explanation: "Made the decision" is a wordy nominalization of "decided," and "for the reason that" is a circumlocution for "because." Choice B uses both concise forms.
source_section: Section II: The Editor's Lens and Economy

prompt: The researcher who was conducting the experiment noticed an anomaly that was significant in the data set.

choices.B: The researcher conducting the experiment noticed a significant anomaly in the data set.
choices.C: The researcher who was the one conducting the experiment noticed an anomaly that happened to be significant in the data set.
choices.D: While conducting the experiment, the researcher who was involved noticed that there was a significant anomaly present in the data set.

explanation: The relative clauses "who was conducting" and "that was significant" are unnecessarily wordy. Choice B replaces them with a participial phrase and a simple adjective, achieving concision without changing meaning.
source_section: Section II: The Editor's Lens and Economy

prompt: Which revision most concisely expresses the idea? "The consensus of opinion among the faculty was that the curriculum needed revision."

choices.A: The consensus of opinion among the faculty was that the curriculum needed revision.
choices.B: The general consensus of opinion among the faculty members was that the curriculum was in need of revision.
choices.C: The faculty consensus was that the curriculum needed revision.
choices.D: The consensus of the shared opinion of the faculty was that the curriculum needed to be revised.

explanation: "Consensus" already means agreement of opinion, so "of opinion" is pleonastic. "Among the faculty" can be shortened to "faculty consensus." Choice C removes all unnecessary words.
source_section: Section II: The Editor's Lens and Economy

prompt: Which option is most concise while preserving meaning? "It is important to note that the experiment yielded inconclusive results."

choices.A: It is important to note that the experiment yielded inconclusive results.
choices.B: What is important to note is that the experiment yielded results that were inconclusive.
choices.C: Notably, the experiment yielded inconclusive results.
choices.D: It should be noted as important that the experiment yielded results that were inconclusive in nature.

explanation: "It is important to note that" is a wordy filler phrase. "Notably" captures the same emphasis in a single word, making Choice C the most concise option.
source_section: Section II: The Editor's Lens and Economy

prompt: Which revision best replaces the underlined portion? "The committee postponed the hearing _for the purpose of allowing_ additional testimony to be gathered."

choices.B: with the intention of allowing for
choices.C: to allow
choices.D: so as to be able to allow

explanation: "For the purpose of allowing" is a circumlocution. "To allow" expresses the same purpose relationship in two words instead of five, making it the most concise and direct choice.
source_section: Section II: The Editor's Lens and Economy

prompt: Which option most concisely states the idea? "The professor asked the students to record and write down their observations during the field study."

choices.A: to record and write down their observations
choices.B: to record and write down their observations in written form
choices.C: to record their observations
choices.D: to record and also write down and document their observations

explanation: "Record" and "write down" are synonymous in this context, making one of them redundant. Choice C uses only "record," which is sufficient and concise.
source_section: Section II: The Editor's Lens and Economy

prompt: Which option is the most concise replacement for the underlined phrase? "The dean _has the ability to_ override the committee's recommendation."

choices.B: is someone who has the ability to
choices.C: can
choices.D: is able to potentially

explanation: "Has the ability to" is a wordy way of expressing "can." Choice C replaces five words with one while preserving the meaning completely.
source_section: Section II: The Editor's Lens and Economy

prompt: Which revision eliminates the pleonasm? "The two candidates held a joint collaboration to develop shared policy proposals."

choices.A: held a joint collaboration to develop shared policy proposals
choices.B: held a joint collaboration together to develop shared policy proposals for both of them
choices.C: collaborated to develop policy proposals
choices.D: held a joint collaborative effort together to develop their shared policy proposals

explanation: "Joint collaboration" is pleonastic because collaboration already implies a joint effort. "Held a collaboration" is also a wordy nominalization. Choice C uses the verb "collaborated" and removes "shared," which is implied by the collaboration.
source_section: Section II: The Editor's Lens and Economy

prompt: Which option best replaces the underlined portion to improve concision? "The experiment failed _as a consequence of the fact that_ the calibration was incorrect."

choices.A: as a consequence of the fact that
choices.B: because
choices.C: as a direct result of the circumstances surrounding the fact that
choices.D: owing to the reason that

explanation: "As a consequence of the fact that" is a seven-word circumlocution that can be replaced by "because." Choice B is the most direct and concise way to express causation.
source_section: Section II: The Editor's Lens and Economy

prompt: Which option most concisely conveys the meaning? "The study, which was lengthy in duration, examined the effects of prolonged screen exposure on adolescent cognition."

choices.A: The study, which was lengthy in duration,
choices.B: The lengthy study
choices.C: The study, which was one that was lengthy in its duration,
choices.D: The study, being one that was of a lengthy duration,

explanation: "Which was lengthy in duration" is a wordy relative clause. "Lengthy" already implies duration, so "in duration" is unnecessary. Choice B converts the clause to a simple adjective, achieving maximum concision.
source_section: Section II: The Editor's Lens and Economy

prompt: Which revision eliminates unnecessary words? "The professor issued a written memo in writing to all department faculty members."

choices.A: issued a written memo in writing to all department faculty members
choices.B: issued a memo to all department faculty members in writing
choices.C: issued a memo to department faculty
choices.D: issued a written memo that was in writing to the faculty members of the department

explanation: "Written memo in writing" is pleonastic: a memo is by definition written. "All department faculty members" can be shortened to "department faculty" without losing meaning. Choice C is the most concise.
source_section: Section II: The Editor's Lens and Economy
